item.title: Apache MINA vs. Netty
item.dc:creator: @dain_bramage dain bramage
item.description:
@dain_bramage wrote:

Didn’t watch the video but out of the two, I would consider Netty better. It seems to be faster and more light-weight then MINA.

Java’s NIO is the best btw.

item.title: Apache MINA vs. Netty
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Could it be your implementation of MINA that’s causing the issue? Based on your information (how the same issue happens slowly over time) it sounds like you have a leak whenever a packet is sent, which doesn’t make sense because I’m pretty sure that doesn’t normally happen with MINA…

item.title: Apache MINA vs. Netty
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

I really don’t think that’s the best way to test it…

You’re only testing each framework’s ability to handle packets from a single connection.

Do it with 1k or so connections.

Read full topic

item.title: Apache MINA vs. Netty
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

I am assuming netty is the second one?

Object and I talked over msn a while back regarding networking and he made an interesting point (especially with his project) that a source should not rely on any single networking API but instead be able to switch networking with the click of a button. The point across is that one should not rely on others code. If a networking API becomes outdated it can easily be updated to the next best thing.

If you did not know the creator/lead dev of MINA is the creator/lead dev of Netty. So obviously he can see his old mistakes and current knowledge to make something better.

Also RSCD did not make the best use of MINA.

Read full topic
